PCDC_SUBJECT_ID.description: A unique identifier for a subject in a study.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker. An individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re- identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

DATA_CONTRIBUTOR_ID.description: An identifier assigned to a data contributor.

UK.description: An information system in the United Kingdom designed for the collection, storage, and management of data on persons with sarcoma.
implementation_notes: (United Kingdom Sarcoma Registry)

GPOH.description: A research organization in Germany involved in the understanding, diagnosis, treatment and prognosis of pediatric cancers.
implementation_notes: (German Pediatric Oncology-Hematology Society)

SSG.description: A research organization in Scandinavia involved in the understanding, diagnosis, treatment and prognosis of sarcoma in children and adolescents.
implementation_notes: (Scandinavian Sarcoma Group)

FSG.description: A research organization in France involved in the understanding, diagnosis, treatment and prognosis of sarcoma in children and adolescents.
implementation_notes: (French Sarcoma Group)

EURO-EWING.description: A coalition of clinical study groups bringing together active clinicians and scientists in Europe dedicated to improving survival from Ewing sarcoma.

ISG.description: A independent, scientific non-profit association formed in 2002 with the purpose of improving the quality of treatment for sarcoma.
implementation_notes: (Italian Sarcoma Group)

CRCTU.description: A research organization in the United Kingdom specializing in the design and delivery of every aspect of clinical trials of all phases in adults and children, from concept to publication.
implementation_notes: (Cancer Research Clinical Trials Unit)

UCL.description: A public research university located in London, England.
implementation_notes: University College of London

COG.description: An NCI-supported clinical cooperative group formed by the merger of the four national pediatric cancer research organizations: the Children's Cancer Group, the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group, the National Wilms Tumor Study Group, and the Pediatric Oncology Group. The primary objective of the organization is to conduct clinical trials of new therapies for childhood and adolescent cancer. COG develops and coordinates clinical trials conducted at the 238 member institutions that include cancer centers of all major universities and teaching hospitals throughout the U.S. and Canada, as well as sites in Europe and Australia. COG members include over 5000 cancer researchers.
implementation_notes: Children's Oncology Group

STUDY_ID.description: A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize the study.

AEWS1221.description: The identifier AEWS1221, assigned to a study in an EWS clinical trial.

AGE_AT_ENROLLMENT.description: Age of subject (in days) when the subject enrolled in the study.

TREATMENT_ARM.description: A specific treatment plan within a clinical trial that describes the activities a subject will be involved in as he or she progresses through the study.

3W-VDC-MESNA+IFO-GCSF/AEWS0031.description: The treatment arm 3W-VDC-MESNA+IFO-GCSF of EWS study AEWS0031.
implementation_notes: Note: Contributor provides a descriptive code that the user can understand. For examples see tab "Treatment Arms".

VIDE-Surgery-R2-VAI-VAI/BuMel/AEWS0331.description: The treatment arm VIDE-Surgery-R2-VAI-VAI/BuMel of EWS study AEWS0331.

VIDE-Surgery-R3-VAI-MEME/TreoMel/BuMel/P.description: The treatment arm VIDE-Surgery-R3-VAI-MEME/TreoMel/BuMel/P2 of EWS study AEWS0331.

VIDEC/AEWS1031.description: The treatment arm VIDEC of EWS study AEWS1031.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The stage or period of an individual's disease.

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.
implementation_notes: Note: Disease phase could be "Initial Diagnosis" phase, or a "Relapse/Progression" phase.

Relapse.description: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

Progression.description: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

AGE_AT_DISEASE_PHASE.description: Age of subject (in days) at the disease phase.

YEAR_AT_DISEASE_PHASE.description: Year when the diagnosis was made for the disease phase.

COURSE.description: The type of protocol treatment course administered.

Induction.description: The first choice of treatment for a particular type of cancer.

Consolidation.description: Treatment that is given after initial therapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.

Maintenance.description: Continuation of treatment for an extended period of time to prevent relapse.

COURSE_NUMBER.description: The number assigned to a course of therapeutic agent administration, indicating where a particular course of treatment falls within a sequence of treatments.

AGE_AT_TXASSIGN.description: Age in Days at Treatment Assignment

AGE_AT_COURSE_START.description: Age of subject (in days) at the start of the course.

AGE_AT_COURSE_END.description: Age of subject (in days) at the end of the course.

AGE_OFF.description: Age of subject (in days) when subject was off therapy or study.

OFF_TYPE.description: The code used to designate that the subject went off therapy or off the study.

Study.description: No longer participating in a study; not being followed and will not be retreated.

REASON_OFF.description: A coded value specifying why the subject is removed from a study.

Death.description: Specifies whether the life of an entity has ceased.
implementation_notes: Note: If multiple reasons "off protocol therapy" or "off study", include one observation per reason.

Completion of Planned Therapy.description: The end of the planned treatment.

Physician Decision.description: A position, opinion or judgment reached after consideration by a physician with reference to subject.

Subject/Guardian Refused Further Treatme.description: The subject or their guardian has refused further treatment.

Disease Progression.description: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.

Development of SMN.description: A malignant neoplasm that arises from a pre-existing lower grade lesion, or as a result of a primary lesion that has spread to secondary sites, or due to a complication of a cancer treatment.

Other.description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

SEX.description: The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.

Male.description: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

Female.description: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces ova. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, or cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

RACE.description: A geographic ancestral origin category that is assigned to a population group based mainly on physical characteristics that are thought to be distinct and inherent.

American Indian or Alaska Native.description: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment. (OMB)
implementation_notes: Note: May not get from some european countries.

Asian.description: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent, including for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam. (OMB)

Black or African American.description: A person having origins in any of the Black racial groups of Africa. Terms such as "Haitian" or "Negro" can be used in addition to "Black or African American". (OMB)

Multiracial.description: Having ancestors of several or various races.

Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islande.description: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands. (OMB)

White.description: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa. (OMB)

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ETHNICITY.description: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition that is maintained from generation to generation. Members share a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group. They have similar and distinctive features in their lifestyle habits and shared experiences. They often have a common genetic heritage which may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.

Hispanic or Latino.description: A person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. The term, "Spanish origin," can be used in addition to "Hispanic or Latino." (OMB)

Not Hispanic or Latino.description: A person not of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

MEDICAL_HISTORY.description: The verbatim description of the medical history being reported.

Fanconi Anemia.description: An autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by bone marrow failure, skeletal abnormalities, and an increase incidence of development of neoplasias.
implementation_notes: Note: If subject had multiple prior medical conditions, include one observation per condition.

Lynch Syndrome.description: An autosomal dominant hereditary neoplastic syndrome characterized by the development of colorectal carcinoma and a high risk of developing endometrial carcinoma, gastric carcinoma, ovarian carcinoma, renal pelvis carcinoma, and small intestinal carcinoma. Patients often develop colorectal carcinomas at an early age (mean, 45 years). In the majority of the cases the lesions arise from the proximal colon. At the molecular level, high-frequency microsatellite instability is present.

Breast and Ovarian Cancer.description: An autosomal dominant inherited syndrome caused by mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes. Patients are at high risk of developing breast cancer, particularly before the age of fifty, high risk of developing a second primary breast cancer, and high risk of developing both breast and ovarian cancer.

Li-Fraumeni.description: An autosomal dominant hereditary neoplastic syndrome caused by an alteration in the p53 tumor suppressor gene. It is characterized by the development of malignant neoplasms at various anatomic sites. The malignant neoplasms associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome include adrenal cortex carcinoma, astrocytic tumors, colorectal carcinoma, gastric carcinoma, malignant breast neoplasms, medulloblastoma, osteosarcoma, and soft tissue sarcomas.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

CAUSE_OF_DEATH.description: The circumstance or condition that results in the death of a living being.

Disease Progression.description: An indication that the subject has died due to the progression of their disease.
implementation_notes: Note: If multiple causes of death, include one observation per cause of death. However, only one cause of death can have the varaiable CAUSE_OF_DEATH_RANKING=Primary. Note: Only fill in this variable if LKSS is "Dead".

Treatment-Related Mortality.description: A death that is considered to be causally linked to a treatment.

Development of SMN.description: A malignant neoplasm that arises from a pre-existing lower grade lesion, or as a result of a primary lesion that has spread to secondary sites, or due to a complication of a cancer treatment.

Other.description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

CAUSE_OF_DEATH_RANKING.description: Assigning a weighted relevance to the cause of death.

Primary.description: The first significant event which ultimately led to death.
implementation_notes: Note: There may be multiple contributory causes of death, but only one primary cause of death. Note: Only fill in this variable if LKSS is "Dead".

Contributory.description: Any factor contributing to the cause of death.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LANSKY.description: The play-performance scale for children is a parent-rated instrument which records usual play activity as the index of performance. It is similar to the Karnofsky Performance Scale for adults.

90.description: Minor restrictions in physically strenuous activity.

70.description: Both greater restriction of and less time spent in play activity.

60.description: Up and around, but minimal active play; keeps busy with quieter activities.

50.description: Gets dressed, but lies around much of the day; no active play, able to participate in all quiet play and activities.

40.description: Mostly in bed; participates in quiet activities.

30.description: In bed; needs assistance even for quiet play.

20.description: Often sleeping; play entirely limited to very passive activities.

10.description: No play; does not get out of bed.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

KARNOFSKY.description: An index designed for classifying patients 16 years of age or older by their functional impairment.

100.description: Normal; no complaints; no evidence of disease.

90.description: Able to carry on normal activity; minor signs or symptoms of disease.

80.description: Normal activity with effort; some sign or symptoms of disease.

70.description: Cares for self; unable to carry on normal activity or do active work.

60.description: Requires occasional assistance, but is able to care for most personal needs.

50.description: Requires considerable assistance and frequent medical care.

40.description: Disabled; requires special care and assistance.

30.description: Severely disabled; hospitalization is indicated, although death not imminent.

20.description: Very sick; hospitalization necessary; active support treatment is necessary.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

GPOH_SCORE.description: A measure of an individual's overall performance status or ability to perform their activities of daily living.

2 - mild complaints, but needs no assist.description: Mild complaints, but needs no assistance.

4 - confined to bed, needs nursing care.description: Confined to bed, needs nursing care.

5 - needs intensive care, seriously ill,.description: Needs intensive care, seriously ill, moribund.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_TUMOR_ASSESSMENT.description: Age of subject (in days) at tumor assessment.

TUMOR_DETECTION_METHOD.description: The technique used to administer the tumor identification assessment.

X-Ray.description: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.
implementation_notes: Note: If there were multiple methods, include one observation per method.

CT Scan.description: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

MRI.description: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Imaging, Not Otherwise Specified.description: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TUMOR_CLASSIFICATION.description: The classification of a tumor based primarily on histopathological characteristics.

Primary.description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.description: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TUMOR_TISSUE_TYPE.description: The type of material sample taken from a biological entity for tumor findings assessment testing.

Bone.description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Soft Tissue.description: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TUMOR_SITE.description: The anatomic site of the tumor.

Abdomen.description: The portion of the body that lies between the thorax and the pelvis.

Abdominal Wall.description: The tissues that surround the organs that are present within the abdominal cavity. The abdominal wall tissue is composed of layers of fat, parietal peritoneum, fascia, and muscles.

Acetabulum.description: Two cup shaped areas, one each on the lateral side of the lower pelvis that house the head of the femur to form the ball and socket joint of the hip.

Ankle.description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Axilla.description: The underside concavity where the arm and the shoulder are joined.

Bone Marrow.description: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Brain.description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Buttock.description: Either of the fleshy mounds in the rear pelvic area of the human body formed by the gluteal muscles.

Calcaneum.description: The irregular and largest tarsal bone that forms the heel.

Carpal Bone.description: Any of the small bones of the wrist joint, located between the radius and the ulna and the metacarpus.

Central Nervous System.description: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Cervical Vertebra.description: Any one of the seven vertebrae that start with C1, connecting the skull to the spine, and ends with C7, which joins the cervical with the thoracic spine.

Chest.description: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.

Chest Wall.description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Clavicle.description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Coccyx.description: A small bone located at the bottom of the spine. The coccyx is a result of 3-5 fused rudimentary vertebrae.

Elbow.description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Ethmoid Bone.description: A light and spongy bone that is cubical in shape. This bone is positioned at the anterior part of the cranium, sitting between the two orbits, at the roof of the nose. It consists of four parts: a horizontal or cribriform plate; a perpendicular plate; and two lateral masses or labyrinths.

Face.description: The anterior portion of the head extending from the forehead to the chin and ear to ear. The facial structures contain the eyes, nose and mouth, cheeks and jaws.

Femur.description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Fibula.description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Fibular Head.description: The highest portion of the fibula that articulates with the patella.

Finger.description: Any of the digits of the hand.

Foot.description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Forearm.description: The structure on the upper limb, between the elbow and the wrist.

Frontal Bone.description: A bone of the skull forming the forehead, root of the nose and the roof of both orbits.

Hand.description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consists of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

Head and Neck.description: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Hip/Inguinal Region.description: The lateral prominence of the pelvis from the waist to the thigh.

Humerus.description: The upper arm bone between the shoulder and elbow.

Ilium.description: The broad, dorsal, upper, and widest of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis.

Intra-Abdominal.description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Ischium.description: The most posterior and ventral bone making up the pelvis.

Kidney.description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secret the metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining the homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Knee.description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Lacrimal Bone.description: A small rectangular thin plate forming part of the medial orbit wall. It is located posterior to the frontal process of the maxilla and articulates with the inferior nasal concha, ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary bones.

Leg.description: One of the two lower extremities in humans used for locomotion and support.

Liver.description: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

Lower Extremity.description: The limb that is composed of the hip, thigh, leg and foot.

Lumbar Vertebra.description: One of the five bones situated between the thoracic vertebrae and the sacrum in the lower part of the spine.

Lung.description: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Lymph Node.description: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Mandible.description: The lower jaw bone holding the lower teeth.

Maxilla.description: The upper jawbone in vertebrates; it is fused to the cranium.

Mediastinum.description: An anatomic site along the midline and under the sternum that contains the heart and pericardium, the bases of the great vessels, the trachea and bronchi, esophagus, thymus, lymph nodes, thoracic duct, phrenic and vagus nerves, and other structures and tissues.

Metacarpus.description: Any of the five bones between the wrist and the fingers that form the skeleton of the palm.

Metatarsus.description: A bone belonging to the middle part of the foot located between toes and ankle. There are 5 metatarsal bones and they are numbered from the medial side.

Nasal Bone.description: One of two small oblong bones placed side by side at the middle and upper part of the face.

Neck.description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Occipital Bone.description: The trapezoidal-shaped bone that forms the back and part of the base of the skull.

Parietal Bone.description: One of two cranial bones that by their union form the sides and roof of the skull.

Patella.description: A small flat triangular bone in front of the knee that articulates with the femur and protects the knee joint.

Pelvis.description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Radius Bone.description: The long bone of the forearm that extends from the lateral aspect of the elbow to the thumb-side of the wrist.

Retroperitoneum.description: Occurring in, or located in the retroperitoneum.

Rib.description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk. The long curved bones which form the rib cage. Generally, ribs 1 to 7 are connected to the sternum by their costal cartilages and are called true ribs, whereas ribs 8 to 12 are termed false ribs.

Sacral Region.description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Scalp.description: The skin which covers the top of the head and which is usually covered by hair.

Scapula.description: The flat triangle-shaped bone that connects the humerus with the clavicle in the back of the shoulder.

Shoulder.description: The region of the body between the neck and the upper arm.

Skull.description: The bones that form the head, made up of the bones of the braincase and face.

Sphenoid Bone.description: The butterfly-shaped bone located at the base of the skull that helps to form the orbit of the eye.

Spinal Cord.description: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.

Spine.description: A series of bones, muscles, tendons, and other tissues reaching from the base of the skull to the tailbone. The vertebral column forms the axis of the skeleton and encloses as well as protects the spinal cord and the fluid surrounding the spinal cord.

Sternum.description: The long, flat bone connecting with the cartilages of the first seven ribs and the clavicle.

Talus.description: The bone of the foot that connects with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

Tarsal Bone.description: Any one of the seven bones forming the instep of the foot.

Temporal Bone.description: A large irregular bone situated at the base and side of the skull, connected with the mandible via the temporomandibular joint. The temporal bone consists of the squamous, tympanic and petrous parts. The petrous portion of the temporal bone contains the vestibulocochlear organ of the inner ear.

Thigh.description: A part of the lower limb, located between hip and knee.

Thoracic Vertebra.description: One of 12 vertebrae in the human vertebral column. The thoracic vertebrae are situated between the seventh cervical vertebra down to the first lumbar vertebra.

Tibia.description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Ulna.description: One of the bones that comprise the forearm. The largest aspect articulates with the humerus at the elbow joint and the smallest portion of the ulna articulates with the carpal bones in the wrist.

Upper Arm.description: The portion of the upper extremity between the shoulder and the elbow. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole superior limb.

Upper Extremity.description: The region of the body that includes the arm, the forearm, and hand.

Wrist.description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Zygomatic Bone.description: The union at the zygomaticotemporal suture of the temporal process of the zygomatic one and zygomatic process of the temporal bone.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TUMOR_LATERALITY.description: A qualifier for the side of the body the tumor findings assessment is performed.

Left.description: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
implementation_notes: Note: Could be primary or metastatic tumor.

Right.description: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.

Bilateral.description: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

Midline.description: A medial line, especially the medial line or medial plane of the body (or some part of the body).

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

SITE_WITHIN_BONE.description: The anatomic site within the long bone.

Distal.description: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.

Proximal.description: Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.

Epiphysis.description: The round end of the long bones.

Metaphysis.description: An area of a long bone located at the junction of the diaphysis and epiphysis, which harbors the epiphyseal plate in immature bones.

Diaphysis.description: The shaft of a long bone, located between the two epiphyses; it is cylindrical in shape, with walls of compact bone enclosing a central marrow cavity.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

FRACTURE.description: A traumatic injury to the bone in which the continuity of the bone is broken.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.
implementation_notes: Note: Linked to each individual site.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LONGEST_DIAM_DIM1.description: The longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

LONGEST_DIAM_DIM2.description: The second longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a nearly circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

LONGEST_DIAM_DIM3.description: The third longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a nearly circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

COMPUTED_VOLUME.description: The International Electrotechnical Commission preferred expression of radiation dose in computed tomography (CT) dosimetry. It is calculated by averaging the radiation dose delivered over x,y and z directions and expressed in the SI unit of Gray (Gy).

<200 mL.description: A finding of a tumor volume that is less than 200 milliters.

>=200 mL.description: A finding of a tumor volume that is equal to or greater than 200 milliters.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

JOINT_INVOLVEMENT.description: A finding indicating the spread of cancer to a joint.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

NODAL_INVOLVEMENT.description: A finding indicating the spread of cancer to regional or distant lymph node(s).

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

SKIP_LESION.description: A benign or malignant pathologic process which is patchy and skips areas which are normal (uninvolved by the pathologic process).

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

IPSILATERAL_NODULES.description: A metastatic tumor nodule located in the same side of the organ in which the primary tumor occurred.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PLEURAL_EFFUSION.description: Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PLEURAL_CYTOLOGY.description: An examination of cells obtained from a sample of pleural fluid.

Negative.description: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Positive.description: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PERITONEAL_EFFUSION.description: The abnormal collection of fluid in the peritoneal cavity resulting in ascites.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PERITONEAL_CYTOLOGY.description: An examination of cells obtained from a sample of peritoneal fluid.

Negative.description: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Positive.description: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

EXTENSION_SITE.description: The anatomical location where metastasis was detected.

Abdominal Wall.description: The tissues that surround the organs that are present within the abdominal cavity. The abdominal wall tissue is composed of layers of fat, parietal peritoneum, fascia, and muscles.

Acetabulum.description: Two cup shaped areas, one each on the lateral side of the lower pelvis that house the head of the femur to form the ball and socket joint of the hip.

Ankle.description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Axilla.description: The underside concavity where the arm and the shoulder are joined.

Buttock.description: Either of the fleshy mounds in the rear pelvic area of the human body formed by the gluteal muscles.

Calcaneum.description: The irregular and largest tarsal bone that forms the heel.

Carpal Bone.description: Any of the small bones of the wrist joint, located between the radius and the ulna and the metacarpus.

Cervical Vertebra.description: Any one of the seven vertebrae that start with C1, connecting the skull to the spine, and ends with C7, which joins the cervical with the thoracic spine.

Chest wall.description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Clavicle.description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Cranium.description: The bones that form the head, made up of the bones of the braincase and face.

Elbow.description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Face.description: The anterior portion of the head extending from the forehead to the chin and ear to ear. The facial structures contain the eyes, nose and mouth, cheeks and jaws.

Femur.description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Fibula.description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Finger.description: Any of the digits of the hand.

Foot.description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Forearm.description: The structure on the upper limb, between the elbow and the wrist.

Hand.description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consists of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

Hip/Inguinal Region.description: The lateral prominence of the pelvis from the waist to the thigh.

Humerus.description: The upper arm bone between the shoulder and elbow.

Intra-abdominal.description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Ischium.description: The most posterior and ventral bone making up the pelvis.

Kidney.description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secret the metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining the homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Knee.description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Leg.description: One of the two lower extremities in humans used for locomotion and support.

Lumbar Vertebra.description: One of the five bones situated between the thoracic vertebrae and the sacrum in the lower part of the spine.

Mandible.description: The lower jaw bone holding the lower teeth.

Maxilla.description: The upper jawbone in vertebrates; it is fused to the cranium.

Metacarpus.description: Any of the five bones between the wrist and the fingers that form the skeleton of the palm.

Metatarsus.description: A bone belonging to the middle part of the foot located between toes and ankle. There are 5 metatarsal bones and they are numbered from the medial side.

Neck.description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Pelvis.description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Radius Bone.description: The long bone of the forearm that extends from the lateral aspect of the elbow to the thumb-side of the wrist.

Retroperitoneum.description: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run.

Rib.description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk. The long curved bones which form the rib cage. Generally, ribs 1 to 7 are connected to the sternum by their costal cartilages and are called true ribs, whereas ribs 8 to 12 are termed false ribs.

Sacral Region.description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Scalp.description: The skin which covers the top of the head and which is usually covered by hair.

Scapula.description: The flat triangle-shaped bone that connects the humerus with the clavicle in the back of the shoulder.

Shoulder.description: The region of the body between the neck and the upper arm.

Sternum.description: The long, flat bone connecting with the cartilages of the first seven ribs and the clavicle.

Talus.description: The bone of the foot that connects with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

Thigh.description: A part of the lower limb, located between hip and knee.

Thoracic Vertebra.description: One of 12 vertebrae in the human vertebral column. The thoracic vertebrae are situated between the seventh cervical vertebra down to the first lumbar vertebra.

Tibia.description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Toe.description: One of the terminal digits of the foot.

Ulna.description: One of the bones that comprise the forearm. The largest aspect articulates with the humerus at the elbow joint and the smallest portion of the ulna articulates with the carpal bones in the wrist.

Upper Arm.description: The portion of the upper extremity between the shoulder and the elbow. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole superior limb.

Wrist.description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Other.description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_HIST_ASSESSMENT.description: Age of subject (in days) at histology assessment.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The stage or period of an individual's disease.

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

Relapse.description: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

Progression.description: The worsening of a disease over time.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

COURSE.description: The type of protocol treatment course administered.

Induction.description: The first choice of treatment for a particular type of cancer.

Consolidation.description: Treatment that is given after initial therapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.

Maintenance.description: Continuation of treatment for an extended period of time to prevent relapse.

COURSE_NUMBER.description: The number assigned to a course of therapeutic agent administration, indicating where a particular course of treatment falls within a sequence of treatments.

HISTOLOGY.description: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs. In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Undifferentiated Ewing Tumor.description: An undifferentiated soft tissue sarcoma characterized by the presence of uniform round or ovoid malignant cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio.
implementation_notes: Note: If multiple histology assessments, include one histology finding.

Neuro-Differentiated Ewing Tumor.description: A small round cell tumor with neural differentiation arising from the soft tissues or bone.

Large Cell Ewing Tumor.description: Ewing sarcoma characterized by the presence of large malignant cells with prominent nucleoli and irregular contours.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_VITALS.description: Age of subject (in days) when vital signs were recorded.

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

Relapse.description: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

Progression.description: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

Maintenance.description: Continuation of treatment for an extended period of time to prevent relapse.

VITALS_TEST.description: The act of assessing an individual's current temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, pulse oxygenation, and blood pressure.

Weight.description: The vertical force exerted by a mass as a result of gravity.
implementation_notes: Note: BMI should only be what is reported on CRF, not calculated from weight and height when submitting data to the PCDC

Height.description: The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.

BMI.description: An individual's weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters.

BSA.description: A measure of the 2-dimensional extent of the body surface (i.e., the skin). Body surface area (BSA) can be calculated by mathematical formula or from a chart that relates height to weight. BSA is often an important factor in dosing.

VITALS_RESULT.description: The outcome of the vital signs assessment.

VITALS_RESULT_NUMERIC.description: The numeric values of the vital signs.

VITALS_RESULT_UNIT.description: The unit used to record and describe the result of a test investigating a vital sign.

kg.description: A basic SI unit of mass. It is defined as the mass of an international prototype in the form of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept at Sevres in France. A kilogram is equal to 1,000 grams and 2.204 622 6 pounds.
implementation_notes: Note: Only fill in this variable if a numeric result is provided in VITALS_RESULT_NUMERIC.

cm.description: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

m2.description: A SI unit of area measurement equal to a square whose sides are one meter long. Square meter is equal to 10,000 square centimeters; 0.01 are; 1.196 square yards; 10.76 square feet; 1550 square inches.

kg/m2.description: The SI derived unit of spread rate of a substance by mass, used also as a measure of area density and as a dose calculation unit.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_LAB.description: Age of subject (in days) at laboratory assessment.

LAB_TEST.description: A character or string that represents the full name of the laboratory assessment.

ESR.description: A quantitative measurement of the distance that red blood cells travel in one hour in a sample of unclotted blood.

LDH.description: A quantitative measurement of the amount of lactate dehydrogenase present in a sample.

LAB_SPEC_TYPE.description: The type of a material sample taken from a biological entity for laboratory testing.

Blood.description: A small volume of blood removed for testing or storage.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LAB_RESULT_NUMERIC.description: A numeric representation of a test result.

LAB_RESULT_UNIT.description: The unit of measure for the original laboratory test result.

U/L.description: An arbitrary unit of substance concentration equal to the concentration at which one liter of mixture contains one unit of a substance.
implementation_notes: Note: Only fill in this variable if a numeric result is provided in LAB_RESULT_NUMERIC.

mm/h.description: A unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector), defined as the distance of one millimeter travelled per unit time equal to one hour.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

THRESHOLD_HIGH.description: The maximum level that must be exceeded for a certain reaction to occur or be manifested.

AGE_AT_IHC.description: Age of subject (in days) at immunohistochemistry assessment.

IHC_TEST.description: A diagnostic test in which an antibody is used to link a cellular antigen specifically to a stain that can be seen with a microscope.

PAS.description: This is an all-round useful stain for many things, including glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoprotein, as well as fungi. The reaction is based on the oxidation of glycol group to aldehydes by periodate. The schiff's reagent selectively stains the aldehydes to a rose pink color. PAS is useful for outlining tissue structures--basement membranes, capsules, blood vessels, etc.

S100.description: A family of low molecular weight proteins that are characterized by the presence of two EF-hand calcium binding domains. These proteins form homodimers that localize either in the cytoplasm or nucleus of neural crest-derived cells and are involved in the regulation of many cellular processes such as cell cycle progression and differentiation.

NSE.description: Gamma-enolase (434 aa, ~47 kDa) is encoded by the human ENO2 gene. This protein is involved in glycolysis, neurotrophy and neuroprotection.

Vimentin.description: Vimentin (466 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human VIM gene. This protein plays a role in the localization of organelles and other cellular components.

Desmin.description: Desmin (470 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human DES gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of cytoskeletal dynamics in muscle cells.

CD99.description: CD99 antigen (185 aa, ~19 kDa) is encoded by the human CD99 gene. This protein plays a role in cell adhesion.

FLI-1.description: Friend leukemia integration 1 transcription factor (452 aa, ~51 kDa) is encoded by the human FLI1 gene. This protein plays a role in the modulation of transcription.

CD45.description: Receptor-type tyrosine-protein phosphatase C (1304 aa, ~147 kDa) is encoded by the human PTPRC gene. This protein plays a role in protein dephosphorylation.

IHC_RESULT.description: The result from the immunohistochemical test.

AGE_AT_MOLECULAR_ANALYSIS.description: Age of subject (in days) when molecular analysis was performed.
